title: A Study to Assess the Steady-State Bioequivalence of Once-Weekly Corplex™ 10mg Donepezil Transdermal Delivery System Compared to Daily Oral Administration of Aricept®
description_brief: A study to assess the steady-state bioequivalence of once-weekly Corplex™ Donepezil 10 mg Transdermal Delivery System (TDS) compared to daily administration of Aricept®
description_detailed:
Open label, randomized, 2-period, multiple-dose crossover study.

Approximately 86 healthy, adult male and female subjects will be enrolled.

Subjects will be randomized to 1 of 2 treatment sequences prior to the first study product treatment in treatment period 1.

For each treatment period; subjects will receive donepezil for 5 consecutive weeks. Blood samples for donepezil PK will be collected pre-dose through week 10.

Adhesion and skin irritation will be monitored throughout TDS treatments. Safety will be monitored throughout the study by adverse event reporting, repeated clinical and laboratory evaluations.
drug: Donepezil (Corplex™ Donepezil Transdermal Delivery System; Aricept® / donepezil hydrochloride)
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is Corplex™ Donepezil TDS (a once-weekly transdermal patch) compared directly to daily oral Aricept® (donepezil). Donepezil is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease (i.e., it improves cognition/symptoms rather than targeting amyloid or tau pathology). citeturn0search3turn1search0

Act: Key extracted details — trial title/description: “A Study to Assess the Steady-State Bioequivalence of Once-Weekly Corplex™ Donepezil 10 mg Transdermal Delivery System Compared to Daily Oral Administration of Aricept®.” The Corplex product delivers donepezil transdermally and was tested for PK/PD bioequivalence to oral donepezil in phase‑1 studies. citeturn0search3turn0search5turn0search2

Reflect: Classification rationale — this trial compares formulations/routes of the same small‑molecule drug donepezil, whose therapeutic action is cholinesterase inhibition to improve cognitive symptoms. That fits the definition of a "cognitive enhancer" (symptomatic cognitive improvement) rather than a disease‑targeted biologic or small molecule aimed at Alzheimer’s pathology (amyloid/tau) or a neuropsychiatric‑symptom intervention. No ambiguity in the mechanism or intent was found in the trial description. citeturn1search0turn0search5

explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational product is donepezil (Corplex™ Donepezil TDS vs oral Aricept®). Donepezil is a centrally acting, reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases synaptic acetylcholine and provides symptomatic cognitive enhancement rather than targeting amyloid or tau pathology. citeturn1search0turn1search5

Act: Key extracted details from the trial — title: 'A Study to Assess the Steady-State Bioequivalence of Once-Weekly Corplex™ 10mg Donepezil Transdermal Delivery System Compared to Daily Oral Administration of Aricept®.' The trial compares formulations/routes of the same cholinergic drug and is a PK/PD/bioequivalence study (Corplex TDS vs oral donepezil). citeturn0search2turn0search3turn0search5

Reflect: Mapping to CADRO — this intervention modulates cholinergic neurotransmission (a neurotransmitter system). Under CADRO, therapies that act on neurotransmitter systems (cholinergic agents, cholinesterase inhibitors) are best classified in D) Neurotransmitter Receptors (neurotransmitter system targets). The trial is symptomatic (cognitive enhancer) and not disease-modifying for amyloid/tau, and it tests formulation/bioequivalence rather than additional biological targets, so 'D) Neurotransmitter Receptors' is the most specific fit. citeturn1search0turn0search2
